awd_titl_txt: CIF: NSF-BSF: Small: Collaborative Research: Characterization and Mitigation of Noise in a Live DNA Storage Channel
awd_abstract_narration:
Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is emerging as a potential solution to growing data storage needs, due to recent advances in DNA synthesis and sequencing. Compared to silicon-based storage, DNA offers higher density and data longevity. Data-bearing DNA can be stored in non-biological environments (in vitro) or be embedded into the DNA of living organisms such as bacteria or plants (in vivo). In vivo DNA data storage benefits from a natural protective shell and a reliable and cost-efficient way to copy data. Furthermore, the compatibility of in vivo storage with living cells creates a potential for advances in synthetic-biology algorithms that require a mechanism for data storage. The goal of this project is to develop and demonstrate an in vivo DNA data storage system that is resilient to errors arising during sequencing and synthesis and from mutations, while achieving the maximum possible data density.

To achieve its goal, the project relies on the following research thrusts: 1) Characterization of the live DNA channel and 2) Error mitigation and correction. Errors in DNA storage are known to be context-dependent, i.e., they depend on the local structure of the sequence. To enable error control, a mathematical model for the channel of live DNA storage will be formulated and the dependence of error rates on sequence context will be characterized. This project will take advantage of new advances in gene-editing technologies, in particular the CRISPR/Cas system, to characterize the channel through experiments. The second thrust aims to overcome the limitations of the existing error-control techniques, which either do not provide adequate error protection or are highly redundant. The project will develop semiconstrained-coding techniques for limiting the frequency of patterns with high error rates and high-rate error-correction schemes for combating errors. The semiconstrained and error-correction methods will be adapted to the live DNA channel and then implemented to evaluate their performance in practice and to demonstrate their advantages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Project

Award Number: 1816965

Project Title: CIF: NSF-BSF: Small: Collaborative Research: Characterization and Mitigation of Noise in a Live DNA Storage Channel

Report Period: Project Outcomes

PI: Jehoshua Bruck

We live in an era of data explosion. It was estimated that the total amount of data generated and replicated in 2020 was 64.2 Zettabytes (1 Zettabyte = 10 to the power 21 bytes) and this amount was projected to be 175 Zettabytes by 2025. Storing data requires enormous space and power coupled with high maintenance cost. To scale-up the storage capacity at a rate comparable to the data growing rate, it is desirable to develop storage technologies that provide high longevity at low cost. The leading proposal, inspired by nature, is a storage solution based on DNA molecules. However, DNA-based information storage is inherently noisy. This project introduced several pioneering research results that solve the key challenges in correcting errors in DNA storage.

There are different types of errors that can occur in information systems. In particular, the most common errors in communications systems are substitution errors (‘year’ can change to ‘dear’ with a single substitution y->d), on the other hand, a deletion error (‘year’ can change to ‘ear’ with a single deletion of y) is common in the emerging field of DNA storage. While the problem of correcting substitution errors is well-studied and enjoyed outstanding progress, the study of correcting deletion errors experienced very limited progress. The study of deletion correcting codes was pioneered by the prominent soviet mathematician Vladimir Levenshtein in 1966 – he proposed an optimal code for correcting a single deletion. However, the problem of constructing optimal codes that can correct multiple deletions has been of interest and open for more than 50 years. We succeeded in solving this problem. We generalized the so-called Levenshtein construction from a single deletion to an arbitrary number of deletions. The journal paper documenting this work appeared in a special issue of the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, by serendipity, this special issue was dedicated to Levenshtein’s memory. Our paper won the 2021 IEEE Data Storage Best Paper Award.

In traditional communications systems, information is sent as long strings of bits, while adding a relatively small number of redundant bits to protect against errors. However, due to limitations in DNA synthesis, writing information in long strings is currently impractical. Namely, in DNA storage, information can be represented only as a collection of relatively very short strings. As a result, the overhead for error correction in DNA storage can be prohibitively too high. We studied the minimal redundancy required for error correction in a collection of short strings and provided novel solutions. The key surprising research contribution is that while the information string is sliced into a set of short strings, the number of redundant bits that are required to correct errors is asymptotically equal to the amount required in the classical error correcting paradigm (with long strings). Namely, there is no penalty for slicing the information sequences into subsequences – a requirement in DNA storage. This result opened the door for exploration of information representations using short sequences that has a vast number of potential applications.

Motivated by the challenge of correcting errors in DNA storage, this project provided solutions to several key longstanding open problems in error-correcting coding theory. Also, it fostered the training of PhD students that, potentially, will emerge as leaders in the evolution of information technology.
